title: Do Not Go Gentle Into That Good Night
text:
Do not go gentle into that good night,
Old age should burn and rave at close of day;
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

Though wise men at their end know dark is right,
Because their words had forked no lightning they
Do not go gentle into that good night.

Good men, the last wave by, crying how bright
Their frail deeds might have danced in a green bay,
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

Wild men who caught and sang the sun in flight,
And learn, too late, they grieved it on its way,
Do not go gentle into that good night.

Grave men, near death, who see with blinding sight
Blind eyes could blaze like meteors and be gay,
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

And you, my father, there on the sad height,
Curse, bless, me now with your fierce tears, I pray.
Do not go gentle into that good night.
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

questions.text: Who is the author of this poem?

clues.text: This poet wrote 'Do Not Go Gentle Into That Good Night' while under contract for the BBC, shortly after WWII. By far one of his most popular works, the poem can be seen as a reflection of the spirit of the people of London after the German air raids.
The poem was originally written while in Florence with his family. This poet is not Italian, however - he's Welsh!
His first and last initials can be found as the first and last letters, respectively, of this work. Neat!

title: Eldorado
author: Edgar Allan Poe
text:
Gaily bedight,
         A gallant knight,
     In sunshine and in shadow,
         Had journeyed long,
         Singing a song,
     In search of Eldorado.

         But he grew old—
         This knight so bold—
     And o’er his heart a shadow
         Fell, as he found
         No spot of ground
     That looked like Eldorado.

         And, as his strength
         Failed him at length,
     He met a pilgrim shadow—
         ‘Shadow,’ said he,
         ‘Where can it be—
     This land of Eldorado?’

         ‘Over the Mountains
Of the Moon,
     Down the Valley of the Shadow,
         Ride, boldly ride,’
         The shade replied,—
     ‘If you seek for Eldorado!’

questions.text: Besides 'Eldorado', what is the most important word in this poem that takes on different meanings each time it is used?

clues.text: It plays a central role in every stanza.
It can imply gloom or despair, a ghost, or the absence of sun.
The final repetition references Psalm 23:4 and possibly suggests that Eldorado (or riches in general) does not exist in the living world, or may be extremely difficult to find in the physical realm.

title: A Poison Tree
author: William Blake
text:
I was angry with my friend:
I told my wrath, my wrath did end.
I was angry with my __?__:
I told it not, my wrath did grow.

And I watered it in fears
Night and morning with my tears,
And I sunned it with smiles
And with soft deceitful wiles.

And it grew both day and night,
Till it bore an apple bright,
And my __?__ beheld it shine,
And he knew that it was mine,

And into my garden stole
When the night had veiled the pole;
In the morning, glad, I see
My __?__ outstretched beneath the tree.

questions.text: What is the missing word in this poem?

clues.text: Expressing themes of indignation and revenge, this poem's original title was 'Christian Forbearance' and may speak to attitudes on anger which were held in Britian at the start of the French Revolution.

This poem was published in 1794 as part of Blake's 'Songs of Experience' collection. The collection was a follow-up to his 1789 'Songs of Innocence.' The two books were later published together under the merged title 'Songs of Innocence and Experience, showing the Two Contrary States of the Human Soul.' It seems Blake enjoys juxtaposing opposites...
This three-letter word rhymes with 'row' (indeed, you might be more likely to have a noisy argument with someone who's your enemy).

title: The Road Not Taken
text:
Two roads diverged in a yellow wood,
And sorry I could not travel both
And be one traveler, long I stood
And looked down one as far as I could
To where it bent in the undergrowth;

Then took the other, as just as fair,
And having perhaps the better claim,
Because it was grassy and wanted wear;
Though as for that the passing there
Had worn them really about the same,

And both that morning equally lay
In leaves no step had trodden black.
Oh, I kept the first for another day!
Yet knowing how way leads on to way,
I doubted if I should ever come back.

I shall be telling this with a sigh
Somewhere ages and ages hence:
Two roads diverged in a wood, and I—
I took the one less traveled by,
And that has made all the difference.

questions.text: Who is the author of this poem?

clues.text: Though a narrative poem, 'The Road Not Taken' is often misinterpreted as autobiographical. However, according to the poet's biographer, the work is more likely based on his friend, the writer Edward Thomas, who he met while spending 1912-1915 in England. After the author returned to New Hampshire in 1915, he sent his friend an advance copy of 'The Road Not Taken'. Thomas took the poem seriously and personally, and it may have been significant in Thomas' decision to enlist in World War I. (Thomas was killed two years later in the Battle of Arras.) In the poet's words, Thomas was 'a person who, whichever road he went, would be sorry he didn't go the other. He was hard on himself that way.'

He is regarded as one of the most popular 20th century poets. A champion of naturalism and the arts, his poetry is accessible for all ages, yet contains a deeper layer that questions mortality and the human condition.
Another famous poem of his is 'Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening'. With snow comes another form of ice - for which his last name is a synonym.

author: Sylvia Plath
text:
I am silver and exact. I have no preconceptions.
Whatever I see I swallow immediately
Just as it is, unmisted by love or dislike.
I am not cruel, only truthful‚
The eye of a little god, four-cornered.
Most of the time I meditate on the opposite wall.
It is pink, with speckles. I have looked at it so long
I think it is part of my heart. But it flickers.
Faces and darkness separate us over and over.

Now I am a lake. A woman bends over me,
Searching my reaches for what she really is.
Then she turns to those liars, the candles or the moon.
I see her back, and reflect it faithfully.
She rewards me with tears and an agitation of hands.
I am important to her. She comes and goes.
Each morning it is her face that replaces the darkness.
In me she has drowned a young girl, and in me an old woman
Rises toward her day after day, like a terrible fish.

questions.text: What single word is the title of this poem?

clues.text: Sylvia Plath is regarded as a pioneer in the genre of Confessional poetry, a term used to define poems which focus on the individual. This poem can be regarded as a retrospective investigation of the self through 'unmisted' eyes. The title also doubles as the dominant metaphor throughout.
The timelessness inherent in this thing is evoked in line 5. Like a god, it is omniscient: able to see and reflect the truth, no matter what the truth looks like as time passes.
A household object as common as a daily routine, this thing explores the life of a woman as an object reflected within it.

title: I Dwell in Possibility
author: Emily Dickinson
text:
I dwell in Possibility –
A fairer House than Prose –
More numerous of Windows –
Superior – for Doors –

Of Chambers as the Cedars –
Impregnable of eye –
And for an everlasting Roof
The Gambrels of the Sky –

Of Visitors – the fairest –
For Occupation – This –
The spreading wide my narrow Hands
To gather Paradise –

questions.text: What does 'Possibility' in this poem most likely refer to?

clues.text: It also begins with a 'p'.
In line 2, it is contrasted with prose, i.e. 'ordinary speech or writing, without metrical structure.'
This poem belongs to the long tradition of ars poetica - literally meaning 'the art of poetry.' For centuries, poets have been writing about the power and beauty of poetry as a vocation and art form.

title: 'Hope' is the thing with feathers
text:
Hope is the thing with feathers –
That perches in the soul –
And sings the tune without the words –
And never stops – at all –

And sweetest – in the Gale – is heard –
And sore must be the storm –
That could abash the little Bird
That kept so many warm –

I've heard it in the chillest land –
And on the strangest Sea –
Yet – never – in Extremity,
It asked a crumb – of me.

questions.text: Who is the author of this poem?

clues.text: Much of this author's poetry is characterized by her own inner strugggles. Though she lived mostly in seclusion, her poetry ofen reveals a fully realized, intricate inner life.

When reading the poem aloud, this poet's use of dashes is said to create a kind of 'visible breath' for the poem to be read aloud in a staccato'd rhythm. This characteristic punctuation is among the most 'widely contested' punctuations in contemporary literary discussions.
This poet's widespread capitalization of common nouns perhaps contributes to a riddle-like quality in many of her poems.

title: The New Colossus
author: Emma Lazarus
text:
Not like the brazen giant of Greek fame,
With conquering limbs astride from land to land;
Here at our sea-washed, sunset gates shall stand
A mighty woman with a torch, whose flame
Is the imprisoned lightning, and her name
Mother of Exiles. From her beacon-hand
Glows world-wide welcome; her mild eyes command
The air-bridged harbor that twin cities frame.
'Keep, ancient lands, your storied pomp!' cries she
With silent lips. 'Give me your tired, your poor,
Your huddled masses yearning to breathe free,
The wretched refuse of your teeming shore.
Send these, the homeless, tempest-tost to me,
I lift my lamp beside the golden door!'

questions.text: What famous statue does the poem depict?

clues.text: Emma Lazarus was commissioned to write a sonnet to help raise funds for a pedestal for this statue. She initially rejected the offer but eventually agreed when pursuaded that the statue would be of great significance to immigrants sailing into the harbor of Ellis Island.
The 'imprisoned lightning' refers to the electric light in the torch of this statue, then a novelty.

The title of the poem and the first two lines reference the Greek Colossus of Rhodes, one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World, a famously gigantic sculpture that stood beside or straddled across the entrance to the harbor of the island of Rhodes in the 3rd century BC. In the poem, Lazarus contrasts that ancient symbol of grandeur and empire with a 'New' Colossus, a female embodiment commanding maternal strength.

title: Section #__?__ , Song of __?__
author: Walt Whitman
text:
The big doors of the country barn stand open and ready,
The dried grass of the harvest-time loads the slow-drawn wagon,
The clear light plays on the brown gray and green intertinged,
The armfuls are pack'd to the sagging mow.

I am there, I help, I came stretch'd atop of the load,
I felt its soft jolts, one leg reclined on the other,
I jump from the cross-beams and seize the clover and timothy,
And roll head over heels and tangle my hair full of wisps.

questions.text: What is the title of this poem?

clues.text: The poem was first published without sections as the first of twelve untitled poems in the first (1855) edition of 'Leaves of Grass'. The first edition was published by Walt Whitman at his own expense.

In the second (1856) edition, Whitman used the title 'Poem of Walt Whitman, an American,' which was shortened to 'Walt Whitman' for the third (1860) edition.

 The poem was divided into fifty-two numbered sections for the fourth (1867) edition and took on the final title in the last edition (1891–2). Funny that today in the age of 'selfies', Whitman's poem might fit right in...

The number of sections is generally thought to mirror the number of weeks in the year. If this interpretation is true, the section number of this portion of the poem would fall in the first week of March.

title: O Captain! my Captain!
author: Walt Whitman
text:
O Captain! my Captain! our fearful trip is done,
The ship has weather’d every rack, the prize we sought is won,
The port is near, the bells I hear, the people all exulting,
While follow eyes the steady keel, the vessel grim and daring;
       But O heart! heart! heart!
         O the bleeding drops of red,
           Where on the deck my Captain lies,
             Fallen cold and dead.

O Captain! my Captain! rise up and hear the bells;
Rise up- for you the flag is flung- for you the bugle trills,
For you bouquets and ribbon’d wreaths- for you the shores a-crowding,
For you they call, the swaying mass, their eager faces turning;
       Here Captain! dear father!
         This arm beneath your head!
           It is some dream that on the deck,
             You’ve fallen cold and dead.

My Captain does not answer, his lips are pale and still,
My father does not feel my arm, he has no pulse nor will,
The ship is anchor’d safe and sound, its voyage closed and done,
From fearful trip the victor ship comes in with object won;
       Exult O shores, and ring O bells!
         But I with mournful tread,
           Walk the deck my Captain lies,
             Fallen cold and dead.

questions.text: What historical figure is the subject of this poem?

clues.text: The poem was first published in the pamphlet 'Sequel to Drum-Taps' which assembled 18 poems regarding the American Civil War (the central event during Walt Whitman's life). The pamphlet included another elegy about this person, entitled 'When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom'd'.

'O Captain! My Captain!' became one of Whitman's most famous poems, one that he would read at the end of his famous lecture about this person's assassination. Whitman became so identified with the poem that late in life he remarked, 'Damn My Captain...I'm almost sorry I ever wrote the poem.'
This person occupied the US presidency corresponding to the number found by multiplying the number of lines in each stanza by 2.

author: Elizabeth Bishop
text:
The art of losing isn't hard to master;
so many things seem filled with the intent
to be lost that their loss is no disaster.

Lose something every day. Accept the fluster
of lost door keys, the hour badly spent.
The art of losing isn't hard to master.

Then practice losing farther, losing faster:
places, and names, and where it was you meant
to travel. None of these will bring disaster.

I lost my mother's watch. And look! my last, or
next-to-last, of three loved houses went.
The art of losing isn't hard to master.

I lost two cities, lovely ones. And, vaster,
some realms I owned, two rivers, a continent.
I miss them, but it wasn't a disaster.

—Even losing you (the joking voice, a gesture
I love) I shan't have lied. It's evident
the art of losing's not too hard to master
though it may look like (Write it!) like disaster.

questions.text: What's the title of this poem?

clues.text: Bishop wrote seventeen drafts of this poem, with titles including 'How to Lose Things,' 'The Gift of Losing Things,' and 'The Art of Losing Things'. By the fifteenth draft, Bishop had settled on the final title.

This poem is considered to be one of the best villanelles in the English Language, and uses an 'ABA' rhyme scheme in each 3-line tercet. The title contains the number representing the difference in syllable count in the poem's alternating lines.
The title contains a word that means something that one gets better at with 'practice'. It can be found within many lines from the 'A' rhyme of this villanelle.

title: Still I Rise
author: Maya Angelou
text:
You may write me down in history
With your bitter, twisted lies,
You may trod me in the very dirt
But still, like dust, I’ll rise.

Does my sassiness upset you?
Why are you beset with gloom?
’Cause I walk like I’ve got oil wells
Pumping in my living room.
Just like moons and like suns,
With the certainty of tides,
Just like hopes springing high,
Still I’ll rise.

Did you want to see me broken?
Bowed head and lowered eyes?
Shoulders falling down like teardrops,
Weakened by my soulful cries?

Does my haughtiness offend you?
Don’t you take it awful hard
’Cause I laugh like I’ve got gold mines
Diggin’ in my own backyard.

You may shoot me with your words,
You may cut me with your eyes,
You may kill me with your hatefulness,
But still, like air, I’ll rise.

Does my sexiness upset you?
Does it come as a surprise
That I dance like I’ve got diamonds
At the meeting of my thighs?

Out of the huts of history’s shame
I rise
Up from a past that’s rooted in pain
I rise
I’m a black ocean, leaping and wide,
Welling and swelling I bear in the tide.

Leaving behind nights of terror and fear
I rise
Into a daybreak that’s wondrously clear
I rise
Bringing the gifts that my ancestors gave,
I am the dream and the hope of the slave.
I rise
I rise
I rise.

questions.text: Maya Angelou was one of the most famous African American writers of the modern era. With which famous figure was she planning to collaborate on the Poor People's March on Washington - an effort to gain economic justice for poor people in the US?

clues.text: Throughout this poem, the types of harrowing and unjust treatment that Black people in America experience are addressed alongside declarations of 'I rise.'

Angelou drew upon blues, gospel and spiritual songs as inspiration for the balladic patterns of this poem. She uses a 'call-and-response' technique that reflects rich African American oral traditions. As such, the power of the poem becomes even more evident when recited aloud - much like the work of her would-be collaborator.

This person's most-famous speech includes the following passage: 'We must forever conduct our struggle on the high plane of dignity and discipline. We must not allow our creative protest to degenerate into physical violence. Again and again, we must rise to the majestic heights of meeting physical force with soul force.' It appears their messages resonate, indeed, that they share the same 'dream' (line 40) for peace, justice, and freedom of opportunity for all.

title: We Real Cool
author: Gwendolyn Brooks
text:
The Pool Players.
        Seven at the Golden Shovel.


            We real cool. We
            Left school. We

            Lurk late. We
            Strike straight. We

            Sing sin. We
            Thin gin. We

            Jazz June. We
            Die soon.

questions.text: What one word did Brooks use to suggest that the pool-playing protagonists in this poem are questioning the validity of their existence?

clues.text: Brooks has said that this word is meant to be said softly when read aloud.

Brooks' inspiration for the poem came from walking past a pool hall full of boys, which led her to ask herself why they weren't in school --and more broadly, “I wonder how they feel about themselves?” With the first two lines as a subtitle for this poem, she thus created the setting and characters, the seven pool players at the Golden Shovel. This word introduces their boasts, which have also been said to reference the 7 Deadly Sins.

Enjambment in poetry is the running on of a sense from line to the next without punctuation, a major pause or syntactical break. This word drives the poem's enjambment throughout, heightening the sense of surprise in the final couplet when 'We / Die soon.' suggests a moment of self-awareness about the choices that the players have made.
